qas.question: What form of c, when written, contains a dot over the letter?
What conventional letter from the Latin alphabet typically replaces the wynn from Old English?
What letter from the Latin alphabet replaces the Old English insular G?
What Latin letter is used in place of the Old English long S?
When eth is replaced, what is it replaced by?
What removes some conventions from Old English manuscripts?
What are used to indicate short vowels?
What kind of vowels have no distinction in Old English?

context: <b5_0>Modern editions<b5_0/> of Old English manuscripts generally introduce some additional conventions. The modern forms of Latin letters are used, including ⟨<a2_0>g<a2_0/>⟩ in place of the insular G, ⟨<a3_0>s<a3_0/>⟩ for long S, and others which may differ considerably from the insular script, notably ⟨e⟩, ⟨f⟩ and ⟨r⟩. <b6_0>Macrons<b6_0/> are used to indicate long vowels, where usually no distinction was made between <b7_0>long and short vowels<b7_0/> in the originals. (In some older editions an acute accent mark was used for consistency with Old Norse conventions.) Additionally, modern editions often distinguish between velar and <a0_0>palatal<a0_0/> ⟨c⟩ and ⟨g⟩ by placing dots above the palatals: ⟨ċ⟩, ⟨ġ⟩. The letter wynn ⟨ƿ⟩ is usually replaced with ⟨<a1_0>w<a1_0/>⟩, but æsc, eth and thorn are normally retained (except when eth is replaced by <a4_0>thorn<a4_0/>).
